Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope
Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope
Pit dug in a Ski Area
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Dug on the bitter end just below the sled. ECT failure was on crust sandwich. Q1, jumped off pit wall. Need some big ANFO shots when we get a load. LAZAR

Overall, the layer of facets at the ground was (in most places) a fairly thin layer. It was also hard to give a hardness because it was a messy mix of facets and ice crusts. The Fx's were F hardness. The crusts were 1 finger hardness. The ECT fractured on a very rough plane. Other pits in the area had similar snow depths (about 1m) and a similar weak layer at the ground. It wasn't too concerning.
Pit for BPG Avy 2 Course

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: 80-79 - Visible layer on the pit wall with SH found surrounded by DF's (Dec 11) 79-66 - RG, however unexpected with cold temps. Suspect 2cm of Facets above Nov23 MFcr that produced RP results with CT's 66-61 - Nov 23 MFcr, 2 laminated crusts with FCrd (1) in between. 35-34 - 3mm P dense MFcr 27-18 - MFcr/FC complex ranging from P-1F. DH(2-5) found between crusts

Collapsing, localized
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Sudden collapse of entire pit wall after excavation and before separating columns for stability test. Observer was not touching the pit wall when collapse happened. Unsure at what depth as there was no clear line of propagation and observer was not looking at the wall. This may have been the reason for no failure in the ECT at the MF/DH interface.

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope; Poor pit location
Snowmobile tracks on slope
Pit is adjacent to avalanche: crown
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Crown profile on approx 30 hr old hard wind slab natural avalanche. Avalanche occurred at treeline. Pit dug on far climber's left end of crown. ECTP failed 11 cm deeper into the weak layer than the avalanche bed surface. I interpreted this to mean that the hard slab is bonding to the weak layer. 2mECT scored 2mECTN breaking 70cm across the 2m column.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry; Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope
Recent activity on different slopes; Ski tracks on slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: the ECTV result was on our second ECT test, and I suspect human error may have prematurely triggered the failure. However, that 3cm layer of loose facets is definitely concerning, and i didn't want to omit that test. We had no results on the interfaces 45 and 70 down however had easy shear results. 45 down seemed like possible NSF while the layer 70 down had 2-3mm SH easily visible.

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Localized wind effect, and drifts that were pencil hard and were sensitive to the weight of a skier, in areas along the NE ridge (from recent northerly winds). These areas did not appear to be widespread. One natural avalanche observed on an upper elevation east/ NE aspect near by, just lookers left of the Fin. The avalanche appeared to have started from a cornice fall.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Time of ascent sky was BKN increased to OVC and started snowing S1. All surrounding/connected slopes were all less than 22º. Facet/crust combo @20cm wasn't planar, undulated around slope. Facets on top of crust could be old surface hoar, no collapse experienced, likely not surface hoar. PST was tough to stay in layer of concern. PST results not representative of conditions.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Crown Profile adjacent to the avalanche that naturally occurred on December 13. SS-N-R3-D2.5-O Crown Depth 60-75cm (24"-30"). Higher than typical crown line. LOTS of soft slab debris chunks in the start zone as well as deep piles on the far skier's right side of the path piled up on the trees at 8550'. Debris reported to have run to within 200 meters of Highway 22.

Pit_Observation.activities: We snowmobiled slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Low hanging clouds, mist, and riming observed on 12/13. Strong winds on 12/13 and the morning of 12/14, approximately 20 hours of steady westerly and northerly wind averaging 16 to 28 mi/hr and gusts to 43 mi/hr starting at 8 am on 12/13. Wind effect and texturing in exposed areas.

Pit_Observation.activities: Snowmobile tracks on slope
Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Very variable HS in area (130-200), rocky. Below cliff band.

East aspects are gaining strength with increased HS and mild temps over the last couple weeks. Continue to see rounding facets near the ground. Nice trend hopeful to see continue. Found facets below a crust buried 20cm below the surface. Likely Radiation Recrystallization, my favorite, elusive weak layer. Did not propagate but it is something to keep an eye on.

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, localized
Collapsing, localized; Cracking

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Old/new interface (12/10 @75cm) produced SP fractures and inconsistent propagation. 12/10 was the culprit in recent small (D1.5) human triggered avalanches in the hwy 542 corridor on northerly aspects above 5500ft. 12/10 is rounding and gaining strength. 11/23 (@50cm) is moist, rounding, and not an issue.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: No pre-Thanksgiving snow in this location. Reactive SH produced long traveling cracks and collapses. Remotely triggered a D2 on this layer (12/7 SH, down about 45cm) about 300m higher in elevation. Remotely triggered a D2.5 at this interface (12/7) that failed on MFcr+FC with a few SH grains visible at crown. S-SE aspect at 10,000'.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Propagating results on 12/7 SH are most immediate concern, but consistent propagating results on 11/26 DH indicate the potential for step-down and larger, unpredictable avalanche activity. Widespread collapsing on 12/7 SH. Interested to see if 12/11 SH will get more talkative with additional loading. Ugly snowpack for riders looking for stability, interesting for folks who like to watch avalanches. Good thing I'm both - you always win.

I place much more value in recent activity and collapses that propagate hundreds of feet than snowpack scores. It is going to get ugly the next few days.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Much shallower and weaker snow on windward SW aspects-like in this snowpit. NW aspects around this area have over 130cm HS. Thin soft slabs forming in exposed areas due to the, blustery, westerly winds. Surface cracking in localized areas. Light density new snow.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Early season check in the snowpack, still a lot of sagebrush poking through.
surprisingly deep and representative of a stable snowpack where the facets are gaining strenght

Pit on small knoll. The pit seems to represent the same thing I was finding by probing with the handle-end of my ski pole many times as I traveled. The basal facets are quite widespread on the upper elevation shady slopes. With a fairly stout slab above, it's probably difficult to trigger but has bad consequences if it does. i avoided slopes steeper than 30 degrees on shady aspects but some other parties got away with skiing them without incident.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Failure below thin sensitive surface windslab would probably propagate in ECT test if layer were thicker.

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope
Pit is adjacent to avalanche: crown; Recent activity on similar slopes; Ski tracks on slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pit dug in crown of snowboard triggered avalanche that occurred midday on Dec 9. Site visit Dec 10. Below to near treeline, open, complex terrain. All CT and ECT failures on top of weak layer at 126cm. One PST run above the crust and the other PST run below the crust.

User.name: Steve Reynaud
User.affil: Tahoe National Forest Sierra Avalanche Center

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, localized
We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Weather was gorgeous BTL /NTL.New and light snow sits upon a solid midpack slab which is supportive for skiing and riding. This pit highlighted our problem layer at the bottom of our snowpack on N-NW slopes near and above treeline. We observed strong and steady snow transport throughout the day off of the summits and high points of Red Mountain Pass. We encountered NW Winds 30+ ATL.
Widespread cracking on low-angle slopes which occurred during a storm to days earlier. This is a profile of one of the cracks on a due north aspect.
Site: Ridge crest feature at treeline. Some previous wind effect.

Continue to see signs that DH is gaining strength. Third day in a row to see moist facets near the ground. Not ready to let my guard down where these things are present however. Upper portion of DH still reactive in stability tests.

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope
We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: No wind crust on surface, pit dug 40 degree NE aspect on sheltered area approx 10 meters below ridge top. Unconsolidated snow easily slides off a near surface faceted layer approx. 10 cm below surface.

User.name: Steve Reynaud

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit is adjacent to avalanche: crown
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Crown profile of remotely triggered avalanche from Dec 7th. It now has about 12 cm of snow plus some wind drifting on top of the crown and bed surface. The avalanche broke on top of facets at 24 cm This path is a REPEATER which previously avalanched during the Thanksgiving week storms.

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, localized
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: This pit shows more settlement(hardness) at the bottom of the snow received since Nov 25. This could be concentrating stresses and making slab more cohesive. Skied this terrain but stayed off the adjacent steeper gully.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Exam Profile. Objectives: Reactivity of slab over 191123 MFcr/FC layer. TL glades above lake/reservoir.

Quick test pit to look at storm snow. A non consistent layer of buried surface hoar found in protected open area in below treeline terrain. V reactive to snowpack tests but showed no other signs of instability. RP results with CT's and ECT's propagate, but were also resistant to coming off block.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pit highlight the decrease in sensitivity and isolated nature of the current hazard. 100cm slab over 15 cm rounding depth hoar. Structure is a red flag but slab is dense and strong. Likelihood of triggering is low but pockets still exist where you can trigger deep slab that may propagate whole slope. NW-E n/atl.
